close_symbols: Object table(s) and record structure(s) referenced by the object-id routines (e.g. the per-type object arrays and the record struct that contains name/buffer fields)
Buffer-size constants used by those records (e.g. OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN or similar)
OS_GetResourceName / OS_IdentifyObject (functions that access object name buffers)
explanation:
For checking MISRA rule about string.h bounds accesses you must inspect not only OS_close but any functions it calls and the data they touch and the buffer sizes involved. Reasons: 

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: immediate callee that validates/obtains the token; may access object tables or copy name buffers. 
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: the internal helpers called by OS_ObjectIdGetById — these can perform array indexing, token-to-index conversions or mem/copy operations on token or object records and must be reviewed for any use of memcpy/str*/memset/etc. 
- OS_GenericClose_Impl: immediate callee that performs the actual close logic; may access per-object data and call other routines that manipulate buffers. 
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: used by GenericClose_Impl to map token -> object index; may dereference or copy object records. 
- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete: called to finalize the delete; may call notification or cleanup code that operates on strings/buffers. 
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish, OS_NotifyEvent: callees of FinalizeDelete; Notify/Finish may build event messages or copy object names (string handling) and are common places where string.h functions are used. 
- OS_object_token_t (type/struct) and osal_id_t: definitions are required to know what pointers/fields are being passed around (are there embedded char arrays, lengths, or pointers?). 
- LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, OS_SUCCESS: constants/macros used by the call sequence; knowing their values/comments can indicate which object table/type is being accessed. 
- Object table(s) and record structure(s): you must inspect the actual object record definitions (their char[] fields and sizes) and the global/per-type object arrays that the id-to-index functions index into to verify any string handling stays within bounds. 
- Buffer-size constants (OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_MAX_PATH_LEN, etc.): needed to reason about maximum lengths and validate memcpy/str*/memset sizes. 
- OS_GetResourceName / OS_IdentifyObject: helper functions that commonly read/write object name buffers; included because object-id routines often call or mirror their behavior and they are likely locations of string.h use. 
- UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr: these appear in the static call graph as callees of OS_close (test-stub hooks). If the build under analysis includes unit-test stubs, those stubs can also call string functions (or instrument return buffers) and therefore must be checked as part of the transitive call graph. 

In short: to prove no out-of-bounds string.h usage you must examine every callee and transitive helper that accesses object records or name buffers and the definitions/sizes of those buffers. The symbols above are the minimal set needed to follow the dataflow from the entry OS_close through token translation, object-table access, close implementation, finalization and any notification/stub code that could invoke string functions.
